text: @realmoney Opening Missive this morning... Jul 24, 2020 | 08:25 AM EDT DOUG KASS Expect the Unexpected as it All Starts Somewhere * Will the Embassy tit for tat be the nail in the market (that many haven't been looking at) and be the catalyst for the market's relentless advance

from March to end? * Yesterday's outside day may have been a dark moment in time for the markets and the beginning of higher tensions between the U.S. and China - and lower stock prices. Overnight, in a tit-for-tat move, China ordered a U.S. consulate closure in the

Southwestern city of Chengdu. Chinese stocks are sharply lower (-5%) this morning On Wednesday I posited that China may retaliate to the U.S. decision to close the Houston consulate - something I cautioned was one of the top 10 factors that could send us into a Bear Market:

Jul 22, 2020 ' 09:50 AM EDT DOUG KASS The U.S./China Rift Heats Up The China/U.S. Rift Widens - China plays "hard ball" in the face of a likely Trump loss. Furious, the President retaliates. Larry Kudlow, the Director of the U.S. National Economic Council, resigns along with

other members of the Administration's economic team (and market confidence falls). (Peter Navarro, assistant to the President and Director of Manufacturing and Trade Policy replaces Sir Larry). Global trade plummets. - Kass Diary, "The Top 10 Factors That Could Send Us Into a

Bear Market This Year" Earlier this week I delivered my Top 10 reasons that could take the averages lower. As I suggested on Monday (see quote above) and noted below by George Magnus, and possibly reflected by the small drop in S&P futures, the schism between the two countries

may have begun to widen. Isn't it always the case, in history, that what appears to be a relatively modest disagreement and retaliation unfolds into something much more significant? I expect that China will retaliate, perhaps closing one of its own embassies/consulates.

Yesterday's Market Contributing to Thursday's market schmeissing was not only the intensification of the relationship between the U.S. and China - but may have been influenced by worsening news on Covid-19 and the decision to move the Republican Convention from Jacksonville,

Florida. Some of Thursday's market features: * The Nasdaq Retreated Broadly - The QQQs were - $6.92 and are down by another -$3 in early pre-market trading to about $255/share. On Monday I made shorting QQQ at $265.50 as my Trade of the Week (so far our gain on the Trade

of the Week is more than +$10!). * Several High Beta, High Profile Nasdaq Stocks Got Schmeissed - Netflix (NFLX) (a recent short) -$12.24, Apple (AAPL) -$17.71, Microsoft (MSFT) -$9.21 (I added to the short), Zoom (ZM) (another recent short) -$9.60, Amazon (AMZN) -$113,

Alphabet (GOOGL) -$48 and Tesla (TSLA) -$80 (after being +$100/share in early trading, I initiated a short and added TSLA to my Best Ideas List (short) * The S&P Suffered - (SPY) was -$3.90. I added to (SDS) in the early morning. * Market Breadth Belied The Broad Weakness -

At only 1460 advancers and 1525 decliners, there were some pockets of strength (e.g., banks traded a bit higher). After the close of trading, Intel (INTC) cut guidance, laying the ground for some further weakness in technology and the Nasdaq this morning (S&P futures are -80

handles). Bottom Line Only with the benefit of hindsight will we know whether the market's fall yesterday is the start of a meaningful decline. As documented, my net short exposure is now at the largest in years - this reflects my process which calculates and concludes that

downside risk dwarfs upside reward. This week Rev Shark did an excellent job in profiling the differences in trading and investing styles and methodolgies. It's a good read for everyone and highlights that there are many ways to skin the market's cat! The fact is that

anticipatory and reactionary approaches are not mutually exclusive in delivering superior trading and investing results. I try to embrace short term price action in some of my trades - though, sometimes, clumsily! However, those that ladder time frames and can embrace both

methodolgies can light it up - in aggregate return terms. As you all know by now, my market/individual stock assessment (reflected in the sizable short disclosures, below) disregards price action/momentum and is predominantly formulated based on where stocks trade today

relative to the price I believe stocks are worth (i.e., "intrinsic" or "fair market value"). And, on that calculus, at least to this observer, stocks remain unattractive. @tomkeene @jimcramer @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @carlquintanilla @realdonaldtrump @bobpisani
@threadreaderapp unroll
Yes Gary I wrote about the comptability of being reactionary and anticipatory - dealing with different timeframes and "laddering" a portfolio. See my opener today.
enjoy and be safe. @threadreaderapp unroll
